awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  CNT-Enhanced carbon fiber structural composite with high performance and spec-tunability
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project will be materials that are lighter weight, tougher and more durable than existing carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites. This will allow companies incorporating these materials into their products to save energy by making products and vehicles that are lighter weight and also to improve range and fuel economy which will subsequently reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In aerospace applications payloads will be reduced saving both money and energy. In defense applications, tougher materials will improve reliability and reduce field repairs, which can be dangerous. In all these applications, the likelihood of catastrophic failures is reduced. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will enhance the strength of carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites (CFRPs) by improving the fiber/matrix integration and developing an interlayer (sizing layer) to protect CFRPs from being broken down by stress accumulated at the interface. This project will minimize or eliminate the interfacial weak points by using a patented surface engineering process. The process functionalizes the surface of the carbon fibers and dramatically promotes the wettability of the matrix resin on the fiber surface. The principal technical objective is to develop a surface engineering process that will improve the fiber/matrix wettability. Distinguished from the reported methods, the proposed surface engineering will process fibers larger than 100 mm in any dimension and more than five plies per load. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) will be added to the sizing polymer to facilitate stress transfer between the carbon fiber reinforcements and the matrix.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The team at Adaxius Corp undertook a significant endeavor to address a critical challenge in composite manufacturing: enhancing the interfacial bonding between carbon fibers and matrix resins. The focal point of this initiative was the development of an innovative Vapor Phase Surface Engineering (VPSE) technique, aimed at improving the wetting properties of carbon materials, which typically exhibit poor interaction with resins due to their inert surface characteristics. This project was not merely an academic exercise but a strategic move towards revolutionizing the efficiency and strength of composite materials for broad industrial application.

The Key Achievements and Technological Innovations include:

VPSE Technique Development: We achieved substantial progress in modifying the surface properties of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and carbon fibers through a VPSE process. This method dramatically lowered the contact angle of these materials, indicating enhanced resin compatibility, accomplished by utilizing the latest atomic/molecular layer deposition technology. The result was a more than tenfold increase in liquid permeation efficiency for treated fabrics compared to untreated ones.

Treatment Uniformity and Scalability: One of the project’s pivotal successes was achieving uniform coating across large areas and volumes, specifically over 12" sizes and processing more than 12 plies in a single load. This accomplishment underscores the VPSE technology's potential scalability and addresses a major hurdle in the surface engineering of composite materials for industrial use.

Significant Savings in Process Precursors: An important achievement of our VPSE process is its efficiency, saving over 80% of the costly reactive vapor precursors. This efficiency is critical for the cost-effective scale-up of the technology, making it a sustainable option for widespread adoption.

Environmental Stability Enhancement: We improved the environmental stability of treated surfaces, extending their stock life significantly. Initially, treated surfaces had a limited stock time, but with the VPSE process, we extended this stability to 60 days, enhancing the practicality of treated composites in varying environmental conditions.

Accelerated Resin Pickup: VPSE-treated carbon reinforcements demonstrated a 50% faster resin absorption compared to untreated controls, a critical advancement for the manufacturing of large composite components, such as wind turbine blades, by notably reducing production times.

Mechanical Performance Enhancement at Concept-Proving Stage: Significant improvements were observed in the mechanical properties of VPSE-treated carbon reinforcements at the concept-proving stage. Single-ply carbon fiber-reinforced composites showed enhancements of 29%, 36%, and 87% in modulus, tensile strength, and toughness, respectively, compared to controls.

Despite these advancements, the project faced challenges, particularly with the reduction in mechanical performance enhancements as the number of reinforcement plies increased. This complexity highlights the need for further investigation to optimize VPSE treatment for multi-ply composite applications. Adhering to our commitment to innovation and stakeholder responsibility, we will postpone the submission of the Phase II proposal until these challenges are addressed.

This Phase I project has laid a foundational stone for substantial future research and development in composite materials technology. By addressing the longstanding issue of poor interfacial bonding and significantly improving the efficiency of composite manufacturing, our work opens up new potential applications across various industries including aviation industry, wind energy, vehicle and sporting goods according to our customer research from the I-Corps program. Future research will focus on optimizing the VPSE process for multi-ply applications, exploring scalability, and enhancing the environmental stability of treated composites.

In conclusion, the Phase I project at Adaxius Corp has made groundbreaking strides in advancing VPSE technology, promising significant future advancements in the field of composite materials engineering. The achievements noted here not only demonstrate the project's success in overcoming technical hurdles but also lay the groundwork for continued innovation and development in this vital area of materials science.

 


Last Modified: 03/24/2024
Modified by: Hongjun Zeng
